sen.e: There was an increase of people called as 'akuto' and their participations in wars during the Period of Southern and Northern courts at least from former powers, and Enshin AKAMATSU and Masashige KUSUNOKI were their representatives.

sen.e: Keiji NAGAHARA stated that military power of the bushi lord of manor from the 12th century to the Period of Southern and Northern Courts when bushidan formed had the house of the same clan as its unit and the army unit cohort consisted of several dozen to two hundred military forces, and many militaristic conquest of a vast area structured the union of house army.

sen.j: 農業生産力の発達と流通の拡大によって、百姓身分の層の中からも、加地子収取権を買い取り集め、日常的営農から解放される層が広範に生まれる。
sen.e: Kajishi (land rent) shutokuken (right to collect land rent) was bought and gathered from even a peasant class with the development and expansion of the circulation of farm production power, and there was a wide range of class born with the release from everyday farming.

sen.j: その層が、地域の封建領主層に結びついて自らも小領主化して地侍となり、守護大名や国人（旧地頭層）と主従関係を持って年貢の一部免除を受けて合戦時には「寄子」クラスの軍役を務める。
sen.e: That class became connected with the feudal lord class, and they themselves became jizamurai (local samurai) as small lords to hold the master and servant relationship with the shugo daimyo (Japanese provincial military governor feudal lords) and kokujin (local samurai) (former jito), exempted from a part of nengu (land tax) and served 'Yoriko' (bushi that served under feudal lords during the Period of Warring States) class military roles during battles.

sen.e: The growth of small lords from villages, and the fusion of that daimyo and kokujin ended the weakened but bearing lasting shoen system.

sen.j: 「武士団」を単なる一般用語としてではなく、「武士」とは別の歴史用語としてあつかうならば、その範囲は11世紀後半から15-16世紀までの、イエ軍団をその類型として、それが戦国時代の、農村から生まれた「寄子」衆に置き換えられていったとも整理することが出来よう。
sen.e: If 'bushidan' is treated not simply as a simple term but a historical term different from 'bushi,' it could be organized as it ranged from the late 11th century to 15th to 16th century as a similar form of family army and was replaced by 'Yoriko' originated from farming villages of the Sengoku Period.
